refnamediv.refpurpose: Creates a GeometryCollection or Multi* geometry from a set of geometries.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Collects geometries into a geometry collection. The result is either a Multi* or a GeometryCollection, depending on whether the input geometries have the same or different types (homogeneous or heterogeneous). The input geometries are left unchanged within the collection.
Variant 1: accepts two input geometries
Variant 2: accepts an array of geometries
Variant 3: aggregate function accepting a rowset of geometries.

note.para: If any of the input geometries are collections (Multi* or GeometryCollection) ST_Collect returns a GeometryCollection (since that is the only type which can contain nested collections). To prevent this, use in a subquery to expand the input collections to their atomic elements (see example below).

ST_Collect and appear similar, but in fact operate quite differently. ST_Collect aggregates geometries into a collection without changing them in any way. ST_Union geometrically merges geometries where they overlap, and splits linestrings at intersections. It may return single geometries when it dissolves boundaries.

refsection.para: Availability: 1.4.0 - ST_Collect(geomarray) was introduced. ST_Collect was enhanced to handle more geometries faster.
&Z_support;
&curve_support;

refsection.title: Examples - Two-input variant
refsection.para: Collect 2D points.
refsection.programlisting:
SELECT ST_AsText( ST_Collect( ST_GeomFromText('POINT(1 2)'), ST_GeomFromText('POINT(-2 3)') ));
st_astext ---------- MULTIPOINT(1 2,-2 3)
refsection.para: Collect 3D points.
refsection.programlisting:
SELECT ST_AsEWKT( ST_Collect( ST_GeomFromEWKT('POINT(1 2 3)'), ST_GeomFromEWKT('POINT(1 2 4)') ) );
st_asewkt ------------------------- MULTIPOINT(1 2 3,1 2 4)
refsection.para: Collect curves.

refsection.title: Examples - Array variant
refsection.para: Using an array constructor for a subquery.
refsection.programlisting: SELECT ST_Collect( ARRAY( SELECT the_geom FROM sometable ) );
refsection.para: Using an array constructor for values.
refsection.programlisting:
SELECT ST_AsText( ST_Collect( ARRAY[ ST_GeomFromText('LINESTRING(1 2, 3 4)'), ST_GeomFromText('LINESTRING(3 4, 4 5)') ] )) As wktcollect;
--wkt collect -- MULTILINESTRING((1 2,3 4),(3 4,4 5))

refsection.title: Examples - Aggregate variant
refsection.para: Creating multiple collections by grouping geometries in a table.
refsection.programlisting: SELECT stusps, ST_Collect(f.the_geom) as geom FROM (SELECT stusps, (ST_Dump(the_geom)).geom As the_geom FROM somestatetable ) As f GROUP BY stusps

refnamediv.refpurpose: Creates a rectangular Polygon from minimum and maximum coordinates.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Creates a rectangular Polygon from the minimum and maximum values for X and Y. Input values must be in the spatial reference system specified by the SRID. If no SRID is specified the unknown spatial reference system (SRID 0) is used.
Availability: 1.5
Enhanced: 2.0: Ability to specify an envelope without specifying an SRID was introduced.

refsection.title: Example: Building a bounding box polygon
refsection.programlisting:
SELECT ST_AsText( ST_MakeEnvelope(10, 10, 11, 11, 4326) );
st_asewkt ----------- POLYGON((10 10, 10 11, 11 11, 11 10, 10 10))

refnamediv.refpurpose: Creates a Linestring from Point, MultiPoint, or LineString geometries.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Creates a LineString containing the points of Point, MultiPoint, or LineString geometries. Other geometry types cause an error.
Variant 1: accepts two input geometries
Variant 2: accepts an array of geometries
Variant 3: aggregate function accepting a rowset of geometries. To ensure the order of the input geometries use ORDER BY in the function call, or a subquery with an ORDER BY clause.

Repeated nodes at the beginning of input LineStrings are collapsed to a single point. Repeated points in Point and MultiPoint inputs are not collapsed. can be used to collapse repeated points from the output LineString.
&Z_support;
Availability: 2.3.0 - Support for multipoint input elements was introduced
Availability: 2.0.0 - Support for linestring input elements was introduced
Availability: 1.4.0 - ST_MakeLine(geomarray) was introduced. ST_MakeLine aggregate functions was enhanced to handle more points faster.

refsection.title: Examples: Two-input variant
refsection.para: Create a line composed of two points.
refsection.programlisting:
SELECT ST_AsText( ST_MakeLine(ST_MakePoint(1,2), ST_MakePoint(3,4)) );
st_astext --------------------- LINESTRING(1 2,3 4)
refsection.para: Create a 3D line from two 3D points.
refsection.programlisting:
SELECT ST_AsEWKT( ST_MakeLine(ST_MakePoint(1,2,3), ST_MakePoint(3,4,5) ));
st_asewkt ------------------------- LINESTRING(1 2 3,3 4 5)
refsection.para: Create a line from two disjoint LineStrings.
refsection.programlisting:
select ST_AsText( ST_MakeLine( 'LINESTRING(0 0, 1 1)', 'LINESTRING(2 2, 3 3)' ) );
st_astext ----------------------------- LINESTRING(0 0,1 1,2 2,3 3)

refsection.title: Examples: Array variant
refsection.para: Create a line from an array formed by a subquery with ordering.
refsection.programlisting: SELECT ST_MakeLine( ARRAY( SELECT ST_Centroid(the_geom) FROM visit_locations ORDER BY visit_time) );
refsection.para: Create a 3D line from an array of 3D points
refsection.programlisting:
SELECT ST_AsEWKT( ST_MakeLine( ARRAY[ ST_MakePoint(1,2,3), ST_MakePoint(3,4,5), ST_MakePoint(6,6,6) ] ));
st_asewkt ------------------------- LINESTRING(1 2 3,3 4 5,6 6 6)

refsection.title: Examples: Aggregate variant
refsection.para: This example queries time-based sequences of GPS points from a set of tracks and creates one record for each track. The result geometries are LineStrings composed of the GPS track points in the order of travel.
Using aggregate ORDER BY provides a correctly-ordered linestring.
Prior to PostgreSQL 9, ordering in a subquery can be used. However, sometimes the query plan may not respect the order of the subquery.
refsection.programlisting: SELECT gps.track_id, ST_MakeLine(gps.geom) As geom FROM ( SELECT track_id, gps_time, geom FROM gps_points ORDER BY track_id, gps_time ) As gps GROUP BY track_id;

refnamediv.refpurpose: Creates a Polygon from a shell and optional list of holes.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Creates a Polygon formed by the given shell and optional array of holes. Input geometries must be closed LineStrings (rings).
Variant 1: Accepts one shell LineString.
Variant 2: Accepts a shell LineString and an array of inner (hole) LineStrings. A geometry array can be constructed using the PostgreSQL array_agg(), ARRAY[] or ARRAY() constructs.

note.para: This function does not accept MultiLineStrings. Use to generate a LineString, or to extract LineStrings.

refsection.para: &Z_support;

refsection.title: Examples: Single input variant
refsection.para: Create a Polygon from a 2D LineString.
refsection.programlisting: SELECT ST_MakePolygon( ST_GeomFromText('LINESTRING(75 29,77 29,77 29, 75 29)'));

refsection.title: Examples: Outer shell with inner holes variant
refsection.para: Create a donut Polygon with an extra hole

Create a set of province boundaries with holes representing lakes. The input is a table of province Polygons/MultiPolygons and a table of water linestrings. Using a LEFT JOIN ensures all provinces are included even if they have no lakes.

note.para: The CASE construct is used because passing a null array into ST_MakePolygon results in a NULL return value.

refsection.programlisting: SELECT p.gid, p.province_name, CASE WHEN array_agg(w.the_geom) IS NULL THEN p.the_geom ELSE ST_MakePolygon( ST_LineMerge(ST_Boundary(p.the_geom)), array_agg(w.the_geom)) END FROM provinces p LEFT JOIN waterlines w ON (ST_Within(w.the_geom, p.the_geom) AND ST_IsClosed(w.the_geom)) GROUP BY p.gid, p.province_name, p.the_geom;
refsection.para: Another technique is to utilize a correlated subquery and the ARRAY() constructor that converts a row set to an array.
refsection.programlisting: SELECT p.gid, p.province_name, CASE WHEN EXISTS( SELECT w.the_geom FROM waterlines w WHERE ST_Within(w.the_geom, p.the_geom) AND ST_IsClosed(w.the_geom)) THEN ST_MakePolygon( ST_LineMerge(ST_Boundary(p.the_geom)), ARRAY( SELECT w.the_geom FROM waterlines w WHERE ST_Within(w.the_geom, p.the_geom) AND ST_IsClosed(w.the_geom))) ELSE p.the_geom END AS the_geom FROM provinces p;

refnamediv.refpurpose: Creates a Point with the given coordinate values. Alias for ST_MakePoint.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns an Point with the given X and Y coordinate values. This is the SQL-MM alias for that takes just X and Y.

note.para: For geodetic coordinates, X is longitude and Y is latitude

refsection.para: &sqlmm_compliant; SQL-MM 3: 6.1.2

refsection.title: Examples: Geometry
refsection.programlisting: SELECT ST_SetSRID( ST_Point( -71.104, 42.315), 4326)

refsection.title: Examples: Geography
refsection.programlisting: SELECT CAST(ST_SetSRID( ST_Point( -71.104, 42.315), 4326) AS geography);
refsection.para: PostgreSQL also provides the :: short-hand for casting
refsection.programlisting: SELECT ST_SetSRID( ST_Point( -71.104, 42.315), 4326)::geography;
refsection.para: If the point coordinates are not in a geodetic coordinate system (such as WGS84), then they must be reprojected before casting to a geography. In this example a point in Pennsylvania State Plane feet (SRID 2273) is projected to WGS84 (SRID 4326).
refsection.programlisting: SELECT ST_Transform(ST_SetSRID( ST_Point( 3637510, 3014852 ), 2273), 4326)::geography;

refnamediv.refpurpose: Creates a rectangular Polygon in Web Mercator (SRID:3857) using the XYZ tile system.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Creates a rectangular Polygon in Web Mercator (SRID:3857) using the XYZ tile system. By default, the bounds are the in EPSG:3857 using the standard range of the Web Mercator system (-20037508.342789, 20037508.342789). The optional bounds parameter can be used to generate envelopes for any tiling scheme: provide a geometry that has the SRID and extent of the initial "zoom level zero" square within which the tile system is to be inscribed.
Availability: 3.0
